#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER XXIV .
#Text=A TANTALIZING REVELATION
#Text=“ I shall have something to tell you in the orchard this evening , ” said the Story Girl at breakfast one morning .
#Text=Her eyes were very bright and excited .
#Text=She looked as if she had not slept a great deal .
#Text=She had spent the previous evening with Miss Reade and had not returned until the rest of us were in bed .
#Text=Miss Reade had finished giving music lessons and was going home in a few days .
#Text=Cecily and Felicity were in despair over this and mourned as those without comfort .
#Text=But the Story Girl , who had been even more devoted to Miss Reade than either of them , had not , as I noticed , expressed any regret and seemed to be very cheerful over the whole matter .
#Text=“ Why ca n’t you tell it now ? ” asked Felicity .
#Text=“ Because the evening is the nicest time to tell things in .
#Text=I only mentioned it now so that you would have something interesting to look forward to all day . ”
#Text=“ Is it about Miss Reade ? ” asked Cecily .
#Text=“ Never mind . ”
#Text=“ I ’ll bet she ’s going to be married , ” I exclaimed , remembering the ring .
#Text=“ Is she ? ” cried Felicity and Cecily together .
#Text=The Story Girl threw an annoyed glance at me .
#Text=She did not like to have her dramatic announcements forestalled .
#Text=“ I do n’t say that it is about Miss Reade or that it is n’t .
#Text=You must just wait till the evening . ”
#Text=“ I wonder what it is , ” speculated Cecily , as the Story Girl left the room .
#Text=“ I do n’t believe it ’s much of anything , ” said Felicity , beginning to clear away the breakfast dishes .
#Text=“ The Story Girl always likes to make so much out of so little .
#Text=Anyhow , I do n’t believe Miss Reade is going to be married .
#Text=She has n’t any beaus around here and Mrs. Armstrong says she ’s sure she does n’t correspond with anybody .
#Text=Besides , if she was she would n’t be likely to tell the Story Girl . ”
#Text=“ Oh , she might .
#Text=They ’re such friends , you know , ” said Cecily .
#Text=“ Miss Reade is no better friends with her than she is with me and you , ” retorted Felicity .
#Text=“ No , but sometimes it seems to me that she ’s a different kind of friend with the Story Girl than she is with me and you , ” reflected Cecily .
#Text=“ I ca n’t just explain what I mean . ”
#Text=“ No wonder .
#Text=Such nonsense , ” sniffed Felicity .
#Text=“ It ’s only some girl ’s secret , anyway , ” said Dan , loftily .
#Text=“ I do n’t feel much interest in it . ”
#Text=But he was on hand with the rest of us that evening , interest or no interest , in Uncle Stephen ’s Walk , where the ripening apples were beginning to glow like jewels among the boughs .
#Text=“ Now , are you going to tell us your news ? ” asked Felicity impatiently .
#Text=“ Miss Reade IS going to be married , ” said the Story Girl .
#Text=“ She told me so last night .
#Text=She is going to be married in a fortnight ’s time . ”
#Text=“ Who to ? ” exclaimed the girls .
#Text=“ To” --
#Text=the Story Girl threw a defiant glance at me as if to say , “ You ca n’t spoil the surprise of THIS , anyway , ” -- “tothe Awkward Man . ”
#Text=For a few moments amazement literally held us dumb .
#Text=“ You ’re not in earnest , Sara Stanley ? ” gasped Felicity at last .
#Text=“ Indeed I am .
#Text=I thought you ’d be astonished .
#Text=But I was n’t .
#Text=I ’ve suspected it all summer , from little things I ’ve noticed .
#Text=Do n’t you remember that evening last spring when I went a piece with Miss Reade and told you when I came back that a story was growing ?
#Text=I guessed it from the way the Awkward Man looked at her when I stopped to speak to him over his garden fence . ”
#Text=“ But -- the Awkward Man ! ” said Felicity helplessly .
#Text=“ It does n’t seem possible .
#Text=Did Miss Reade tell you HERSELF ? ”
#Text=“ Yes . ”
#Text=“ I suppose it must be true then .
#Text=But how did it ever come about ?
#Text=He ’s SO shy and awkward .
#Text=How did he ever manage to get up enough spunk to ask her to marry him ? ”
#Text=“ Maybe she asked him , ” suggested Dan .
#Text=The Story Girl looked as if she might tell if she would .
#Text=“ I believe that WAS the way of it , ” I said , to draw her on .
#Text=“ Not exactly , ” she said reluctantly .
#Text=“ I know all about it but I ca n’t tell you .
#Text=I guessed part from things I ’ve seen -- and Miss Reade told me a good deal -- and the Awkward Man himself told me his side of it as we came home last night .
#Text=I met him just as I left Mr. Armstrong ’s and we were together as far as his house .
#Text=It was dark and he just talked on as if he were talking to himself -- I think he forgot I was there at all , once he got started .
#Text=He has never been shy or awkward with me , but he never talked as he did last night . ”
#Text=“ You might tell us what he said , ” urged Cecily .
#Text=“ We ’d never tell . ”
#Text=The Story Girl shook her head .
#Text=“ No , I ca n’t .
#Text=You would n’t understand .
#Text=Besides , I could n’t tell it just right .
#Text=It ’s one of the things that are hardest to tell .
#Text=I ’d spoil it if I told it -- now .
#Text=Perhaps some day I ’ll be able to tell it properly .
#Text=It ’s very beautiful -- but it might sound very ridiculous if it was n’t told just exactly the right way . ”
#Text=“ I do n’t know what you mean , and I do n’t believe you know yourself , ” said Felicity pettishly .
#Text=“ All that I can make out is that Miss Reade is going to marry Jasper Dale , and I do n’t like the idea one bit .
#Text=She is so beautiful and sweet .
#Text=I thought she ’d marry some dashing young man .
#Text=Jasper Dale must be nearly twenty years older than her -- and he ’s so queer and shy -- and such a hermit . ”
